name: Continuity assessment record and evaluation tool - Post acute care - discharge

items.question: Patient's Facility/Agency Identification Number (for internal tracking)

answers.label: D7
answers.text: Title programs (e.g., Title III, V, or XX)

items.codingInstructions: Clinicians: For this section, please provide a listing of medical diagnoses, comorbid diseases and complications, and procedures based on a review of the patient's clinical records available at the time of assessment. This information is intended to enhance continuity of care.  For discharge only, these can be added to throughout the stay and will be specific to each setting.
items.question: Current Medical Information

items.codingInstructions: Indicate the primary diagnosis and up to 14 other diagnoses being treated, managed, or monitored in this setting. Please include all diagnoses (e.g., depression, schizophrenia, dementia, protein calorie malnutrition).
items.question: Primary and Other Diagnoses, Comorbidities, and Complications
Major Procedures (Diagnostic, Surgical, and Therapeutic Interventions)

items.codingInstructions: List up to 15 procedures (diagnostic, surgical and therapeutic interventions). Indicate if a procedure was left, right, or not applicable (N/A). If procedure was bilateral (e.g., bilateral knee replacement), check both left and right boxes.
items.question: Did the patient have one or more major procedures (e.g., G-tube placement, EEG, abdominal, cat scans; do not include x-rays, EKGs, ultrasounds) during this admission?

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Major treatments discharged with

answers.label: D30
answers.text: Other Major Treatments, e.g. isolation, hypothermia blanket

answers.label: D25
answers.text: Specialty Surface or Bed (i.e., air fluidized, bariatric, low air loss, or rotation bed)

answers.label: D26
answers.text: Multiple Types of IV Antibiotic Administration

answers.label: D21
answers.text: Complex Wound Management with positioning and skin separation/traction that requires at least two persons or extensive & complex wound management by one person

answers.label: D12
answers.text: High O2 Concentration Delivery System with FiO2 > 40%

answers.label: D27
answers.text: IV Vaso-actors (e.g., pressors, dilators, medication for pulmonary edema)

items.question: Specify most intensive frequency of suctioning during stay: Every____ hours

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Major treatments used at any time during stay

answers.label: D30
answers.text: Other Major Treatments, e.g. isolation, hypothermia blanket

answers.label: D25
answers.text: Specialty Surface or Bed (i.e., air fluidized, bariatric, low air loss, or rotation bed)

answers.label: D26
answers.text: Multiple Types of IV Antibiotic Administration

answers.label: D21
answers.text: Complex Wound Management with positioning and skin separation/traction that requires at least two persons or extensive & complex wound management by one person

answers.label: D12
answers.text: High O2 Concentration Delivery System with FiO2 > 40%

answers.label: D27
answers.text: IV Vaso-actors (e.g., pressors, dilators, medication for pulmonary edema)

items.question: Specify most intensive frequency of suctioning during stay: Every____ hours

items.codingInstructions: List all current medications for the patient.
items.question: Medications

answers.label: CAPDINSTL
answers.text: Instillation, continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis port

items.question: Does patient have allergies or any known adverse drug reactions?
Is this patient at risk of developing pressure ulcers?

answers.text: Yes, indicated by high risk by formal assessment (e.g., on Braden or Norton tools) or the patient has a stage I or greater ulcer, a scar over a bony prominence, or a non-removable dressing, device, or cast.

items.question: One or more unhealed pressure ulcer(s) at stage 2 or higher
IF THE PATIENT HAS ONE OR MORE STAGE 2-4 PRESSURE ULCERS, indicate the number of unhealed pressure ulcers at each stage.
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - stage 2
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - stage 3
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - stage 4
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - unstageable
Number of pressure ulcers onset during this service - stage 2
Number of pressure ulcers onset during this service - stage 3
Number of pressure ulcers onset during this service - stage 4
Number of pressure ulcers onset during this service - unstageable
Number of unhealed stage 2 ulcers known to be present for more than 1 month
If any pressure ulcer is stage 3 or 4 (or if eschar is present), please record the most recent measurements for the LARGEST ulcer (or eschar):
Pressure Ulcer Depth: Depth of the same pressure ulcer; from visible surface to the depth of the deepest area
Indicate if any unhealed stage 3 or stage 4 pressure ulcer(s) has undermining and/or tunneling (sinus tract) present.
Major wound (excluding pressure ulcers). Does the patient have one or more major wound(s) that require ongoing care because of draining, infection, or delayed healing?
Vascular ulcer (arterial or venous including diabetic ulcers not located on the foot)

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Turning surfaces not intact

answers.label: a
answers.text: Skin for all turning surfaces is intact

items.question: Vital signs & oximetry - admission, home health, interim, discharge
Please specify source and amount of supplemental O2

items.codingInstructions: This or prior setting acceptable.
items.question: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (%)
Please specify source and amount of supplemental O2
Did the resident receive the Influenza Vaccine in this facility for this year's influenza season (October 1 through March 31)?
If influenza vaccine not received, state reason:

answers.text: Inability to obtain vaccine due to declared shortage
Resident not in  facility during this year's flu season

items.question: Is the resident's Pneumococcal Vaccination up to date?
If Pneumococcal Vaccine not received, state reason:

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Has the patient exhibited any of the following behaviors during the 2-day assessment period?
Physical behavioral symptoms directed toward others
Verbal behavioral symptoms directed towards others.
Other disruptive or dangerous behavioral symptoms not directed towards others, including self-injurious behaviors.

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Mood

items.codingInstructions: During the last 2 weeks, have yo been bothered by any of the following problems?

items.question: Feeling down, depressed or hopeless in last 2W.frequency

answers.text: 7-11 Days (half or more of the days)

items.question: Ask patient: "During the past 2 weeks, how often would you say, 'I feel sad'?"

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Pain
Pain Presence. Ask patient: "Have you had pain or hurting at any time during the last 2 days?"

answers.text: Unable to answer or no response

items.codingInstructions: Enter 88 if patient does not answer or is unable to respond.
items.question: Pain Severity. Ask patient: "Please rate your worst pain during the last 2 days on a zero to 10 scale, with zero being no pain and 10 as the worst pain you can imagine."

answers.text: Patient does not answer or is unable to respond

items.question: Pain Effect on Sleep. Ask patient: "During the past 2 days, has pain made it hard for you to sleep?"

answers.text: Unable to answer or no response

items.question: Pain Effect on Activities. Ask patient: "During the past 2 days, have you limited your activities because of pain?"

answers.text: Unable to answer or no response

items.codingInstructions: Pain Observational Assessment. If patient could not be interviewed for pain assessment, check all indicators of pain or possible pain   Check all that apply.
items.question: Pain Observational Assessment.  If the patient could not be interviewed for pain assessment, check all indicators of of  pain or possible pain.

answers.label: e
answers.text: None of these signs observed or documented

answers.label: a
answers.text: Non-verbal sounds (e.g., crying, whining, gasping, moaning, or groaning)

answers.label: d
answers.text: Protective body movements or postures (e.g., bracing, guarding, rubbing or massaging a body part/area, clutching or holding a body part during movement)

answers.label: b
answers.text: Vocal complaints of pain (e.g., “that hurts, ouch, stop”)

answers.label: c
answers.text: Facial Expressions (e.g., grimaces, winces, wrinkled forehead, furrowed brow, clenched teeth or jaw)

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Bladder and Bowel Management - Use of Device(s) and Incontinence
Does the patient have any impairments with bladder or bowel management (e.g., use of a device or incontinence)?
Bladder - Does this patient use an external or indwelling device or require intermittent catheterization?
Bowel - Does this patient use an external or indwelling device or require intermittent catheterization?
Bladder - Indicate the frequency of incontinence.

answers.text: Incontinence daily (at least once a day)

items.question: Bowel - Indicate the frequency of incontinence.

answers.text: Incontinence daily (at least once a day)

items.question: Bladder - Does the patient need assistance to manage equipment or devices related to bladder or bowel care (e.g., urinal, bedpan, indwelling catheter, intermittent catheterization, ostomy, incontinence pads/undergarments)?

Bowel - Does the patient need assistance to manage equipment or devices related to bladder or bowel care (e.g., urinal, bedpan, indwelling catheter, intermittent catheterization, ostomy, incontinence pads/undergarments)?
Bladder - If the patient is incontinent or has an indwelling device, was the patient incontinent (excluding stress incontinence) immediately prior to the current illness, exacerbation, or injury?
Bowel - If the patient is incontinent or has an indwelling device, was the patient incontinent (excluding stress incontinence) immediately prior to the current illness, exacerbation, or injury?

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Swallowing

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Does the patient have any signs or symptoms of a possible swallowing disorder?

answers.label: d
answers.text: Loss of liquids/solids from mouth when eating or drinking

answers.label: a
answers.text: Complaints of difficulty or pain with swallowing

answers.label: b
answers.text: Coughing or choking during meals or when swallowing medications

answers.label: c
answers.text: Holding food in mouth/cheeks or residual food in mouth after meals

items.question: Describe the patient's usual ability with swallowing.

answers.text: Modified food consistency/supervision: Patient requires modified food or liquid consistency and/or needs supervision during eating for safety.
Regular food: Solids and liquids swallowed safely without supervision and without modified food or liquid consistency.
Tube/parenteral feeding: Tube/parenteral feeding used wholly or partially as a means of sustenance.

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Hearing, Vision, and Communication
Does the patient have any impairments with hearing, vision, or communication?
Understanding verbal content - excluding language barriers

answers.text: Sometimes Understands: Understands only basic conversations or simple, direct phrases. Frequently requires cues to understand
Understands: Clear comprehension without cues or repetitions
Usually Understands: Understands most conversations, but misses some part/intent of message. Requires cues at times to understand
Rarely/Never expresses self or speech is very difficult to understand.
Exhibits some difficulty with expressing needs and ideas (e.g., some words or finishing thoughts) or speech is not clear
Expresses complex messages without difficulty and with speech that is clear and easy to understand
Frequently exhibits difficulty with expressing needs and ideas

items.question: Ability to see in adequate light  (with glasses or other visual appliances)

answers.text: Mildly to Moderately Impaired: Can identify objects; may see large print
Severely Impaired: No vision or object identification questionable
Adequate: Sees fine detail, including regular print in newspapers/books

items.question: Ability to hear (with hearing aid or hearing appliance, if normally used)

answers.text: Mildly to Moderately Impaired: Difficulty hearing in some environments or speaker may need to increase volume or speak distinctly
Severely Impaired: Absence of useful hearing
Adequate: Hears normal conversation and TV without difficulty

items.question: Medication management-oral medications during 2D assessment period

answers.label: E
answers.text: Not attempted due to environmental constraints

answers.label: M
answers.text: Not attempted due to medical condition

answers.label: S
answers.text: Not attempted due to safety concerns
Partial/moderate assistance – Helper does LESS THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts, holds or supports trunk or limbs, but provides less than half the effort.
Setup or clean-up assistance – Helper SETS UP or CLEANS UP; patient completes activity. Helper assists only prior to or following the activity.
Substantial/maximal assistance – Helper does MORE THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts or holds trunk or limbs and provides more than half the effort.
Supervision or touching assistance – Helper provides VERBAL CUES or TOUCHING/ STEADYING assistance as patient completes activity. Assistance may be provided throughout the activity or intermittently.
Dependent – Helper does ALL of the effort. Patient does none of the effort to complete the task.
Independent – Patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance from a helper.

items.question: Medication management-injectable medications during 2D assessment period

answers.label: E
answers.text: Not attempted due to environmental constraints

answers.label: M
answers.text: Not attempted due to medical condition

answers.label: S
answers.text: Not attempted due to safety concerns

Setup or clean-up assistance – Helper SETS UP or CLEANS UP; patient completes activity. Helper assists only prior to or following the activity.

Supervision or touching assistance – Helper provides VERBAL CUES or TOUCHING/ STEADYING assistance as patient completes activity. Assistance may be provided throughout the activity or intermittently.
Dependent – Helper does ALL of the effort. Patient does none of the effort to complete the task.
Independent – Patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance from a helper.

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Weight-bearing
Does the patient have any clinician-ordered weight-bearing or limb/spinal loading restrictions( including upper body lift, push, pull, or carry restrictions)?

items.codingInstructions: CODING: Indicate all the patient's weight-bearing restrictions.
items.question: Weight-bearing restrictions panel

answers.text: Not fully weight-bearing: Patient has clinician ordered restrictions
Fully weight-bearing: No clinician ordered restrictions
Not fully weight-bearing: Patient has clinician ordered restrictions
Fully weight-bearing: No clinician ordered restrictions
Not fully weight-bearing: Patient has clinician ordered restrictions
Fully weight-bearing: No clinician ordered restrictions
Not fully weight-bearing: Patient has clinician ordered restrictions
Fully weight-bearing: No clinician ordered restrictions

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Grip Strength
Does the patient have any impairments with grip strength (e.g. reduced/limited or absent)?

items.codingInstructions: CODING: Indicate the patient's ability to squeeze your hand.
items.question: Grip strength panel

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Respiratory status
Does the patient have any impairments with respiratory status?

answers.text: Mild at rest (during day or night)
Never, patient was not short of breath
Severe, with evidence the patient is struggling to breathe at rest
With moderate exertion (e.g., while dressing, using commode or bedpan, walking between rooms)
With minimal exertion (e.g., while eating, talking, or performing other ADLs) or with agitation
Mild at rest (during day or night)
Never, patient was not short of breath
Severe, with evidence the patient is struggling to breathe at rest
With moderate exertion (e.g., while dressing, using commode or bedpan, walking between rooms)
With minimal exertion (e.g., while eating, talking, or performing other ADLs) or with agitation

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Endurance
Does the patient have any impairments with endurance?
Mobility Endurance: Was the patient able to walk or wheel 50 feet (15 meters)?

answers.text: Not assessed due to medical restriction

items.question: Sitting Endurance: Was the patient able to tolerate sitting for 15 minutes?

answers.text: Not assessed due to medical restriction

items.codingInstructions: Complete during the 2-day assessment period.
items.question: Mobility devices and aids needed

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Indicate all mobility devices and aids needed at time of assessment.

items.codingInstructions:
The core self care items should be completed on ALL patients. Complete during the 2-day assessment period. Code the patient's most usual performance using the 6-point scale below. 

CODING: Safety and Quality of Performance - If helper assistance is required because patient's performance is unsafe or poor quality, score according to amount of assisance provided.  Activities may be completed with or without assistive devices.

answers.label: M
answers.text: Not attempted due to medical condition

answers.label: S
answers.text: Not attempted due to safety concerns

Supervision or touching assistance – Helper provides VERBAL CUES or TOUCHING/ STEADYING assistance as patient completes activity. Assistance may be provided throughout the activity or intermittently.
Dependent – Helper does ALL of the effort. Patient does none of the effort to complete the task.
Independent – Patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance from a helper.

items.codingInstructions:
Supplemental Functional Ability (Complete during the 2-day assessment period.)  Please code the patient on all activities they are able to participate in and which you can observe, or have assessed by other means, using the 6-point scale below.

Coding: Safety and Quality and Performance - If helper assistance is required because patient's performance is unsafe or poor quality, score according to amount of assistance provided.  Code for the most usual performance in the 2-day assessment period.  Activities may be completed with or without assistive devices.

items.question: Overall Plan of Care &or Advance Care Directives
Overall Plan of Care/Advance Care Directives
Have the patient (or representative) and the care team (or physician) documented agreed-upon care goals and expected dates of completion or re-evaluation?

answers.text: No, but this work is in process

items.question: Which description best fits the patient's overall status?

answers.text: The patient has serious progressive conditions that could lead to death within a year.
The patient is likely to remain in fragile health and have ongoing high risks of serious complications and death.
The patient is stable with no risk for serious complications and death (beyond those typical of the patient’s age).
The patient is temporarily facing high health risks but likely to return to being stable without risk for serious complications and death (beyond those typical of the patient’s age).
The patient’s situation is unknown or unclear to the respondent.

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: In anticipation of serious clinical complications, has the patient made care decisions which are documented in the medical record?

answers.text: The patient has designated a decision-maker (if the patient is unable to make decisions) which is documented in the medical record.
The patient (or surrogate) has made a decision to forgo resuscitation which is documented in the medical record.

items.question: Discharge Location. Where will the patient be discharged to?

answers.text: Other (e.g., shelter, jail, no known address)
Other community-based residential setting (e.g., assisted living residents, group home, adult foster care)

items.question: Frequency of Assistance at Discharge (or admission for HH). How often will the patient require assistance (physical care or supervision) from a caregiver(s) or provider(s)?

answers.text: Weekly or less (e.g., requires help with grocery shopping or errands, etc.)
24 hours per day, or standby services
All day but not at night
All night but not during the day
Intermittently and predictably during the day or night
Less than daily but more often than weekly

items.question: Caregiver(s) Availability. Was the discharge destination decision influenced by the availability of a family member or friend to provide assistance?
Willing Caregiver(s). Does the patient have one or more willing caregiver(s)?

answers.text: Unclear from patient; no confirmation from caregiver

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Types of Caregiver(s). What is the relationship of the caregiver(s) to the patient?

answers.label: c
answers.text: Other unpaid family member or friend

items.codingInstructions: Complete only if patient is discharged to a private residence or other community-based setting.
items.question: Residential Information

items.codingInstructions: Check all that apply.
items.question: Patient Lives With at Discharge (or admission for HH). Upon discharge (admission), who will the patient live with?

items.codingInstructions: Type of Assistance Needed. Patient needs assistance with (check all that apply). Support Needs/Caregiver Assistance. (If patient needs assistance, check one on each row).
items.question: Support Needs &or Caregiver Assistance
ADL assistance (e.g., transfer/ambulation, bathing, dressing, toileting, eating/feeding)

answers.text: CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services

items.question: IADL assistance (e.g., meals, housekeeping, laundry, telephone, shopping, finances)

answers.text: CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services

items.question: Medication administration (e.g., oral, inhaled, or injectable)

answers.text: CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services
CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services

items.question: Management of equipment (includes oxygen, IV/infusion equipment, enteral/parenteral nutrition, ventilator therapy equipment, or supplies)

answers.text: CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services
CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services

items.question: Advocacy or facilitation of patient's participation in appropriate medical care (includes transportation to or from appointments)

answers.text: CG not likely to be able
CG will need training and/or other supportive services

items.question: None of the above or non-residential setting

items.codingInstructions: Please indicate whether the team considered the  following services appropriate for the patient at discharge; for those identified as potentially appropriate, were they: unavailable, refused by family, or not covered by insurance. (Check all that apply.)
items.question: Discharge Care Options
Is the patient being discharged with referral for additional services?

items.question: National provider ID
Was the patient's discharge delayed for at least 24 hours?

answers.text: Services, equipment or medications not available (e.g., home health care, durable medical equipment, IV medications)
Family/support (e.g., family could not pick patient up)

items.question: In the situation that the patient or an authorized representative has requested this information not be shared with the next provider, check here:

items.codingInstructions: Coders: For this section, please provide a listing of principal diagnosis, comorbid diseases and complications, and procedures based on a review of the patient's clinical records at the time of discharge or at the time of a significant change in the patient's status affecting Medicare payment.
items.question: Medical Coding Information

items.codingInstructions: Indicate the principal diagnosis for billing purposes. Indicate the ICD-9 CM code. For V-codes, also indicate the medical diagnosis and associated ICD-9 CM code. Be as specific as possible.
items.question: Principal Diagnosis

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: ICD-9 CM for Principal Diagnosis at Assessment

items.codingInstructions: List other diagnoses being treated, managed, or monitored in this setting.  Include all diagnoses (e.g., depression, schizophrenia, dementia, protein calorie malnutrition).
items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: If Prinicipal Diagnosis was a V-code, what was the ICD-9 CM code for the primary medical condition or injury being treated?
Major Procedures (Diagnostic, Surgical, and Therapeutic Interventions)

items.codingInstructions: List up to 15 ICD-9 CM codes and associated procedures (diagnostic, surgical, and therapeutic interventions) performed this admission.
items.question: Did the patient have one or more major procedures (e.g., G-tube placement, EEG, abdominal, cat scans; do not include x-rays, EKGs, ultrasounds) during this admission?

items.codingInstructions: Thank you for your participation in this important project. So that we may improve the form for future use, please comment on any areas of concern or things you would change about the form.
items.question: Is there other useful information about this patient that you want to add?
